issue.title: Fix bug in SslContext private key reading fall-back path

repository.name: netty
repository.description: Netty project - an event-driven asynchronous network application framework

issue.body:
Motivation:
We first try to read private keys with BouncyCastle, and then fall back to our own code if that fails.
It could be the case, that BouncyCastle read some data before it failed, and in that case we need to make sure that our fallback code gets to read the key data from the original stream position - not whatever position caused a failure in BouncyCastle.

Modification:
Use the mark and reset methods of InputStream to reset the key stream position, if BouncyCastle cannot read a key.
If the provided input stream does not already support marking, then we wrap it in a BufferedInputStream which does.
We allow up to 1 MiB of data to be buffered for this purpose.
If the key is bigger than this, and BouncyCastle reads more than this before failing, then resetting will throw an exception so we don't get silent failures.

Result:
Fixed private key fallback code path.
Fixes #12745

body: Thanks for the report. This should be fixed by https://github.com/netty/netty/pull/12746
Thank you for the quick fix!

issue.title: TLS: support PKCS#1 certificates

labels.name: good first issue
labels.description: These are recommended starting points for newcomers looking to make their first contributions.

labels.name: hacktoberfest
labels.description: Global event that encourages people to contribute to open-source.

labels.name: triaged
labels.description: Issues labeled as 'Triaged' have been reviewed and are deemed actionable.

repository.name: security
repository.description: üîê Secure your cluster with TLS, numerous authentication backends, data masking, audit logging as well as role-based access control on indices, documents, and fields

issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
TLS keys in the PKCS#1 format should be supported as well.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
it should be possible to use also PKCS#1 certificates.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
most systems also allow generating PKCS#8 certificates or they can be manually converted.
for us it works to generate PKCS#8, however it's not the default of cert-manager.

for those using cert-manager, you can add the following to your `Certificate` k8s custom resource:
```yaml
apiVersion: cert-manager.io/v1
kind: Certificate
# ...
spec:
# ...
  privateKey:
    encoding: PKCS8 # required by OpenSearch Security, it can't handle PKCS1 (which is the default of cert-manager)
```

**Additional context**
* PKCS#1 is the default for certificates generated by cert-manager, see the [`CertificatePrivateKey` specification](https://cert-manager.io/docs/reference/api-docs/#cert-manager.io/v1.CertificatePrivateKey)
* see also #52 (i decided to create a dedicated new ticket for this as it's not limited to Let's Encrypt and the other ticket seems to contain other topics as well)
* e.g. Search Guard supports PKCS#1 as well.

when starting OpenSearch Security 1.2.3.0 with PKCS#1 keys you get the following error in the log:
```
{"type": "server", "timestamp": "2022-01-14T08:18:14,945Z", "level": "ERROR", "component": "o.o.s.s.DefaultSecurityKeyStore", "cluster.name": "test-opensearch", "node.name": "test-opensearch-0", "message": "Your keystore or PEM does not contain a key. If you specified a key password, try removing it. If you did not specify a key password, perhaps you need to if the key is in fact password-protected. Maybe you just confused keys and certificates." }
```
